title: Wisdom and Authority
shortSummary: Proverbs 29 offers profound insights on leadership, righteousness, and human behavior, emphasizing the consequences of folly and the blessings of wisdom. It contrasts the outcomes of just and wicked rulers and highlights the importance of discipline, humility, and trust in the Lord for a stable society.
timeline: c. 10th century BC - Solomon's Proverbs compilation

keyCharacters.name: The Righteous
keyCharacters.description: Those who live according to God's wisdom and justice, bringing joy and stability to society.

keyCharacters.name: The Wicked
keyCharacters.description: Individuals who reject wisdom and justice, causing sorrow, destruction, and societal decay.

keyCharacters.name: The King/Ruler
keyCharacters.description: A leader whose judgment can establish or overthrow the land, depending on his integrity and justice.

keyCharacters.name: The Fool
keyCharacters.description: A person lacking wisdom who speaks rashly and acts without understanding, causing unrest.

definitions.definition: A biblical idiom meaning to stubbornly resist correction or discipline.
A symbol of discipline and correction, often used in the context of child-rearing.
Divine guidance or revelation that directs a people or leader toward righteous living.
To use insincere praise to manipulate or deceive others.

outline.heading: Consequences of Stubbornness and Leadership
outline.description: This section warns against resisting correction and contrasts the joy brought by righteous rulers with the mourning caused by wicked ones, emphasizing the king's role in establishing justice.

outline.heading: Human Behavior and Wisdom
outline.description: Focuses on interpersonal conduct, highlighting the dangers of flattery, anger, and foolish speech, while celebrating the joy and consideration of the righteous.

outline.heading: Justice, Discipline, and Social Order
outline.description: Addresses the importance of truthful leadership, faithful judgment, and the role of discipline in raising children who bring peace and delight.

outline.heading: Vision, Speech, and Relationships
outline.description: Stresses the necessity of divine vision for societal survival, the dangers of hasty words and anger, and the consequences of associating with thieves or fearing man over God.

outline.heading: Trust in God and Moral Contrast
outline.description: Concludes by affirming that trust in the Lord brings safety, while human judgment is ultimately from God, contrasting the abominations between the just and the unjust.

application: Embrace correction and discipline as means to grow in wisdom and avoid sudden destruction.
Pray for and support righteous leadership that seeks justice and governs with integrity.
Guard your speech and emotions, practicing patience and self-control to maintain peace.
Trust in the Lord rather than fearing man, knowing Godâ€™s judgment is supreme and just.

keyVerses.text: Where there is no vision, the people perish: but he that keepeth the law, happy is he.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the necessity of divine guidance and obedience to God's law for the survival and happiness of a people.

keyVerses.text: The fear of man bringeth a snare: but whoso putteth his trust in the LORD shall be safe.
keyVerses.significance: It teaches that fearing human opinion can trap believers, but trusting God provides true security.

keyVerses.text: The king that faithfully judgeth the poor, his throne shall be established for ever.
keyVerses.significance: Highlights the eternal stability granted to rulers who administer justice with faithfulness and care for the vulnerable.

keyVerses.text: A fool uttereth all his mind: but a wise man keepeth it in till afterwards.
keyVerses.significance: Emphasizes the wisdom of restraint in speech, contrasting it with the impulsiveness of folly.
